edu.rit.io

Class InStream

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.rit.io.InStream

  • public class InStream
extends Object
    Class InStream provides an object that reads primitive data types, strings, objects, and arrays in binary form from an underlying input stream. It reads a byte stream that was written using class OutStream as described in more detail in the individual methods.

    The methods for reading integer types and strings read a variable number of bytes, as described in more detail in the individual methods of class OutStream. This can save space in the byte stream if small integer values are written more frequently than large integer values.

    Several methods for reading objects are provided:

    • readFields() reads just the fields of a Streamable object. Use this method when the reader knows the class of the object ahead of time and has already created an instance of that class.

    • readObject() reads both the class name and the fields of a Streamable or Serializable object. Use this method when the reader does not know the class of the object ahead of time.

    • readReference() reads the class name and the fields of a Streamable or Serializable object, and also keeps a reference to the object. If the same object is read by readReference() again, just a reference to the previous object is returned. Use this method when the reader needs to end up with multiple references to the same object.

    Classes OutStream and InStream provide a lightweight object serialization capability—one that generates fewer bytes than Java Object Serialization in package java.io. However, the programmer is responsible for writing all the serialization and deserialization code in each class that implements interface Streamable.

    To support interoperability with classes designed to work with Java Object Serialization, readObject() and readReference() will work both on Streamable objects and on Serializable objects. In the latter case, a byte array is read, and the byte array is converted to an object using Java Object Serialization.

    Methods for reading arrays of primitive types, strings, and objects are provided. Methods for reading multidimensional arrays are not provided; you can read a multidimensional array by reading a series of single-dimensional arrays.

    Class InStream includes buffering. Blocks of bytes are read from the underlying input stream and stored in an internal buffer. Items are then read from the internal buffer.

    Note: Class InStream is not multiple thread safe.

        public InStream(InputStream in)
        Construct a new in stream. The internal buffer size is the default (8192 bytes).
        Parameters:

        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if in is null.

      • InStream

        public InStream(InputStream in,
        int size)
        Construct a new in stream with the given internal buffer size.
        Parameters:
        in - Underlying input stream.
        size - Internal buffer size ≥ 1 (bytes).
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if in is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if size < 1.

    • Method Detail

      • readBoolean

        public boolean readBoolean()
                    throws IOException
        Read a Boolean value from this in stream. One byte is read, either 0 (false) or 1 (true).

        To write the value, the writer must call OutStream.writeBoolean(boolean).

        Returns:
        Boolean value.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • readFields

        public <T extends Streamable> T readFields(T v)
                                throws IOException
        Read the given object's fields from this in stream. The fields are read by calling v.readIn(). v must not be null.

        To write the value, the writer must call OutStream.writeFields().

        Type Parameters:
        T - Data type of the object.
        Parameters:
        v - Object.
        Returns:
        Object that was read, namely v.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if v is null.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • readObject

        public Object readObject()
                  throws IOException
        Read an object from this in stream. An index is read using readUnsignedInt(). If the index is 0, null is returned. Otherwise, the index designates the object's class; if this is the first occurrence of the class, the class name is read using readString(); either (a) for a streamable object, a new object is constructed using the class's no-argument constructor and the object's fields are read by calling readFields(), or (b) for a serializable object, a byte array is read and the byte array is converted to an object using Java Object Serialization; and the object is returned.

        To write the value, the writer must call OutStream.writeObject().

        Note: If the same object is written multiple times using writeObject(), the reader will end up with multiple different objects (that are copies of each other). If the reader needs to end up with multiple references to the same object, use writeReference().

        Note: The calling thread's context class loader is used to retrieve the class, given the class name.

        Note: When constructing a new instance of a streamable object, access checks are suppressed. This means the object's class and/or the class's no-argument constructor need not be public, and a new instance will still be constructed. However, this also requires that either (a) a security manager is not installed, or (b) the security manager allows ReflectPermission("suppressAccessChecks"). See the java.lang.reflect.Constructor.setAccessible() method for further information.

        Returns:
        Object, or null.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred. Thrown if the object could not be deserialized.

      • readReference

        public Object readReference()
                     throws IOException
        Read a reference to an object from this in stream. An index is read using readUnsignedInt(). If the index is 0, null is returned. Otherwise, the index designates the object reference; if this is the first occurrence of the object, the object is read using readObject(), and the object is saved in a cache so that later calls to readReference() will return a reference to the saved object; and the object reference is returned.

        To write the value, the writer must call OutStream.writeReference().

        Note: If the same object is written multiple times using writeReference(), the reader will end up with multiple references to the same object. If the reader needs to end up with multiple different objects (that are copies of each other), use writeObject().

        Returns:
        Object reference, or null.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred. Thrown if the object could not be deserialized.

      • clearCache

        public void clearCache()
        Clear the cache of objects that have been read using readReference(). Afterwards, this in stream will act as though no objects had been previously read using readReference().

        The reader must call clearCache() at the same point as the writer called OutStream.clearCache().

      • readBooleanArray

        public boolean[] readBooleanArray()
                           throws IOException
        Read a Boolean array from this in stream. The length is read using readInt(). If the length is −1, null is returned. Otherwise, a new array of the given length is created, and each element of the array is read using readBoolean().

        To write the array, the writer must call OutStream.writeBooleanArray(boolean[]) or OutStream.writeBooleanArray(boolean[],int,int).

        Returns:
        Boolean array, or null.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • readBooleanArray

        public void readBooleanArray(boolean[] v)
                      throws IOException
        Read the given Boolean array from this in stream. The length is read using readInt(). If the length is not the same as the length of v, an exception is thrown. Otherwise, each element of v is read using readBoolean().

        To write the array, the writer must call OutStream.writeBooleanArray(boolean[]) or OutStream.writeBooleanArray(boolean[],int,int).

        Parameters:
        v - Boolean array.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if v is null.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • readBooleanArray

        public void readBooleanArray(boolean[] v,
                    int off,
                    int len)
                      throws IOException
        Read a portion of the given Boolean array from this in stream. The length is read using readInt(). If the length is not the same as len, an exception is thrown. Otherwise, len elements starting from v[off] are read using readBoolean().

        To write the array, the writer must call OutStream.writeBooleanArray(boolean[]) or OutStream.writeBooleanArray(boolean[],int,int).

        Parameters:
        v - Boolean array.
        off - Index of first element to read.
        len - Number of elements to read.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if v is null.
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if off < 0, len < 0, or off+len > v.length.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • readByteArray

        public byte[] readByteArray()
                     throws IOException
        Read a byte array from this in stream. The length is read using readInt(). If the length is −1, null is returned. Otherwise, a new array of the given length is created, and each element of the array is read using readByte().

        To write the array, the writer must call OutStream.writeByteArray(byte[]) or OutStream.writeByteArray(byte[],int,int).

        Returns:
        Byte array, or null.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if v is null.
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if off < 0, len < 0, or off+len > v.length.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • readIntArray

        public int[] readIntArray()
                   throws IOException
        Read an integer array from this in stream. The length is read using readInt(). If the length is −1, null is returned. Otherwise, a new array of the given length is created, and each element of the array is read using readInt().

        To write the array, the writer must call OutStream.writeIntArray(int[]) or OutStream.writeIntArray(int[],int,int).

        Returns:
        Integer array, or null.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • readIntArray

        public void readIntArray(int[] v)
                  throws IOException
        Read the given integer array from this in stream. The length is read using readInt(). If the length is not the same as the length of v, an exception is thrown. Otherwise, each element of v is read using readInt().

        To write the array, the writer must call OutStream.writeIntArray(int[]) or OutStream.writeIntArray(int[],int,int).

        Parameters:
        v - Integer array.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if v is null.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • readIntArray

        public void readIntArray(int[] v,
                int off,
                int len)
                  throws IOException
        Read a portion of the given integer array from this in stream. The length is read using readInt(). If the length is not the same as len, an exception is thrown. Otherwise, len elements starting from v[off] are read using readInt().

        To write the array, the writer must call OutStream.writeIntArray(int[]) or OutStream.writeIntArray(int[],int,int).

        Parameters:
        v - Integer array.
        off - Index of first element to read.
        len - Number of elements to read.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if v is null.
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if off < 0, len < 0, or off+len > v.length.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • readObjectArray

        public Object[] readObjectArray()
                         throws IOException
        Read an array of objects from this in stream. The length is read using readInt(). If the length is −1, null is returned. Otherwise, the array element class is read, a new array of the given length and the given element class is created, and each element of the array is read using readObject().

        To write the array, the writer must call OutStream.writeObjectArray(Object[]) or OutStream.writeObjectArray(Object[],int,int).

        Returns:
        Object array, or null.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred. Thrown if the object array could not be deserialized.

      • readObjectArray

        public void readObjectArray(Object[] v)
                     throws IOException
        Read the given object array from this in stream. The length is read using readInt(). If the length is not the same as the length of v, an exception is thrown. Otherwise, the array element class is read. If this is not the same as (or a subclass of) the element class of v, an exception is thrown. Otherwise, each element of v is read using readObject().

        To write the array, the writer must call OutStream.writeObjectArray(Object[]) or OutStream.writeObjectArray(Object[],int,int).

        Parameters:
        v - Object array.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred. Thrown if the object array could not be deserialized.

      • readObjectArray

        public void readObjectArray(Object[] v,
                   int off,
                   int len)
                     throws IOException
        Read a portion of the given object array from this in stream. The length is read using readInt(). If the length is not the same as len, an exception is thrown. Otherwise, the array element class is read. If this is not the same as (or a subclass of) the element class of v, an exception is thrown. Otherwise, len elements starting from v[off] are read using readObject().

        To write the array, the writer must call OutStream.writeObjectArray(Object[]) or OutStream.writeObjectArray(Object[],int,int).

        Parameters:
        v - Object array.
        off - Index of first element to read.
        len - Number of elements to read.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred. Thrown if the object array could not be deserialized.

      • readReferenceArray

        public Object[] readReferenceArray()
                            throws IOException
        Read an array of object references from this in stream. The length is read using readInt(). If the length is −1, null is returned. Otherwise, the array element class is read, a new array of the given length and the given element class is created, and each element of the array is read using readReference().

        To write the array, the writer must call OutStream.writeObjectArray(Object[]) or OutStream.writeObjectArray(Object[],int,int).

        Returns:
        Object array, or null.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred. Thrown if the object reference array could not be deserialized.
